transcript.text: [Music]
hi and welcome you listening to the x 22
report my name is dave and this is
episode 1216 a and today's date is
februari 28 2017 and the title of the
episode is last time we saw credits ease
up we were in a recession well it's
happening now now before I get started I
just want to make an announcement i
uploaded in an interview with simon
blankies from sovereign mancom if you go
over to the x 22 report spotlight
youtube channel you'll see the video
there or you can come over to the x 22
report com site scroll down a little bit
look over the right hand side you'll see
the video there or you can go to news
sentinel com same thing scroll down a
little bit look over to your right hand
side and you can play the video there
let's get into the economic collapse
financial news now in Greece we talked
about how people are taking their
currency out of the banks and what we're
seeing right now is that this is
accelerating it is not slowing people
are continually taking more and more of
their currency and what we're seeing
right now is that bank deposits they've
tumble to the lowest since 2001 in the
banks and the situation there is getting
worse and this is why they said listen
we can't do balance right now in Greece
because it will hurt the creditors and
what's happening is is that the outflow
of currency well it's making it very
difficult to do balance and people
realize this they understood what would
happen because they look at Cypress and
they knew that if they keep their
currency in the bank it would be trapped
there so this made it more and more
difficult for them to do a balun and
again my personal opinion is only keep
as much as you possibly can in the bank
because if we get into or when we get
into that Baylen situation guess what
we're going to have a bank holiday the
system is going to shut down you will
not be able to get your currency it will
be stuck in the bank they'll be capital
controls that will put that will be put
into effect and you will not be able to
get any of your hard-earned currency now
I would personally keep currency on hand
I would keep gold and silver as an
insurance policy we can see right now
that
the former fed Greenspan he's saying
yeah I would keep gold as an insurance
policy countries now are loading up on
gold so I would do the exact same thing
now in almost 20 states right now we see
that they have raised the gas prices
remember when the gas prices came down
well our government officials thought
this would be a perfect opportunity to
raise gas taxes and we can see that
nearly 20 states well they raise gas
taxes or we calculated the gas tax
formulas hoping that no one would notice
because the price of fuel is much lower
than it was and we can see right now
there are many states that are adding on
30 40 cents or more than 40 cents to the
fuel out there now what's going to
happen is that as people pay more and
more towards fuel well guess what this
is going to hurt once again it's not
going to make the situation situation
better it's almost like the soda tax in
philadelphia where they thought oh let's
put a tax on this we're going to get all
this new revenue and then all of a
sudden well things started going the
other way people bought less sold soda
hurting the distributor's the bottlers
and we can see right now this is what's
going to happen I mean right now the
demand for fuel is declining and once
this gas tax goes into effect and many
states that already has the demand is
going to sink even lower it's going to
be a horrible situation we see that GM
well it looks like they're doing exactly
what they did back in two thousand eight
when things go bad what do you do you
give out incentives because incentive
surged to over eighty percent now we
understand that we're in an auto bubble
we understand that there's delinquents
the delinquency rate is moving up and up
and up it's not getting better and when
we look
at the subprime securitization book we
see that in January of 2017 delinquency
rates they're soaring to the highest
level since 2009 early 2010 and this
does not look good meanwhile looking at
GM subprime data going back two thousand
one implies historical spikes and two
months Lincoln see rates is fairly
decent indicator that all is not well
and what we see now is that GM is
offering these massive incentives and
guess what they did this before and the
company went bankrupt for it I mean
discounts are averaging about 6996 for
like the chevrolet silverado 5315 for
the GMC sierra and when all this is said
and done this is not going to turn out
well we saw this back into the prior to
two thousand eight and we know what
happened to the auto industry it was a
complete disaster now a couple months
ago we know that the government
officials were out there and there and
the corporate media was out there saying
yes minimum wage minute let's raise it
up let's let's do this this is going to
help the people and people are going
back and forth saying yes minimum wage
will help minimum wage will not help and
we're starting to see the case where
minimum wage is actually not helping now
remember the value of the dollar is
declining if we do not go to the source
of the problem which is the central bank
raising the minimum wage over and over
and over is not going to help we've done
this since 1970 do you see any
improvement at all or have things gotten
a lot worse and what companies are doing
today like Wendy's like Walmart Home
Depot McDonald's they're putting in
robots self
ow systems where they don't need people
and guess what Wendy's right now has
figured out how to eliminate 31 hours of
labor per week from its restaurants
because they looked at raising the
minimum wage and they said well wait a
minute can we afford this no we can't or
maybe we can't afford it but we want to
make more profits let's bring in the
self-checkout terminals and this is what
many of the companies are doing and if
you notice those are growing while the
people actually checking you out is
shrinking right now because they realize
let the people check themselves out we
need one person standing there they can
handle five different kiosks and we
don't have to pay five people that's
exactly what they're doing we see
there's a retail apocalypse going on
right now now we've been tracking retail
quite a bit here and we know that retail
is completely suffering and it's not
because of the weather it's not because
people are shopping online it's because
people don't have work and if they do
they're making a lot less than they were
once before and they're holding on to
their currency and what we're seeing
right now is that in 2016 it was a very
rough year for the retailers and we see
that Arab us telepacific son american
apparel and many others well they went
for and they declared chapter 11
bankruptcy protection sports authority
same thing now according to Moody's
retail credit analyst Charlie O'Shea the
environment for retailers in the u.s. is
likely to get worse before getting
better Moody's notes the number of
distress US retailers has more than
tripled as tripled since the Great
Recession so what kind of recovery is
this not too great and with 5 billion
worth of debt maturities over the next
four years the situation is going to get
much much worse so who's next where
they're going to be declaring bankruptcy
or we're going to see stores closing
what Clare's j.crew
tops route 21 well they're all having
problems the 19 retail portfolio Oh
roughly five billion in debt through
2020 one with about forty percent of
this due by the end of 2018 so we're
moving into a situation where we're
going from bad to absolutely awful and
as we move forward it is not going to
get any better whatsoever we see
case-shiller is out and they're saying
well mortgage rates are rising but
that's no problem home prices in our 20
cities they are doing very well well not
really because when you look at the
graph of the case-shiller home price
year-on-year remember their live there
only looking at certain number of cities
they have been really flatlined since
2014 they hit their height in December
of 2013 since that time they've been
declining and they've been flatlined
since June of 2014 to the present day
and what we're going to see is that
these prices are going to come down even
further now when we look outside of the
20 cities guess what we see houses on
the market they can't sell them prices
are being lowered and lowered and
lowered we see they finally came out
with the one point nine percent gdp for
a fourth quarter and again this is a
manipulated number Obama care premiums
are including this because this is part
of consumer spending which makes up 71
percent of GDP they revised numbers
going backwards to bring this number up
and this is what they do very often they
do these type of things to completely
make it look like the economy is

2016 GDP is that one point six percent
which is actually awful and it is a
manipulated number which means that this
GDP number is much much lower if we go
to shadow stats we can see that GDP
isn't a negative territory now
back in 2008 we had a credit crisis
where credit completely froze up today
we're seeing the same things and when we
look at commercial banks all their loans
and leases and things like that we see
from the board of governors of the fair
reserve well they're at their 25% peak
of the prior credit bubble in october
two thousand eight since the week ending
december 7 2016 they've declined a
smidgen so why is that all important
that this is flattened out after soaring
for so many years and how do these
companies fit into this problem well the
period from October 19th until now is
the first extended stretch of a stalling
commercial and industrial loans since
the bottom of the financial crisis now
commercial industrial and loans have
been moving up and up and up until
October 19th and here we are in February
and we can see at this point what is
happening is that we're seeing it turned
down now when we look at this we say oh
what's the big deal every time the
credit stalls at the peak we are in a
recession if we go back to two thousand
eight prior to 2008 we hit a high of
commercial and industrial loans of all
commercial banks they'd hit a peak and
it started a decline we were in a
recession if we go back to 2001 the same
thing to go back in time we see the same
thing happen so going back to nineteen
eighty-eight covering the last three
recessions the turning points show that
we're in a recession and that is what
we're seeing right now it is happening
again it's an early warning sign of a
gradual change in
dynamics and this is a red flag showing
us something is happening and we saw
back in two thousand eight credit froze
up guess what's going to happen again
credit is going to freeze up completely
now we see that the central bank's it
looks like they have unleashed inflation
we're seeing that Spain well they
reported a year-over-year seven point
five percent jump in inflation Germany
seeing the same thing the u.s. guess
what inflation is over two percent
heading towards three percent and it's
moved up just right at three percent
right now and it's moving up very fast
and the big problem with inflation it's
like catch up in a bottle you know it's
hard to get out you hit it you shake it
and it just doesn't come out but when
you get it going you can't stop it and
it just gets all over the place this is
what inflation this is what's going to
happen with inflation the Federal
Reserve the other central banks they
were trying to get it started we know it
was happening in the background but now
they Unleashed it and it's going to move
very very quickly and they will not be
able to control it once it gets out of
whack here and we can see that's coming
very very quickly we see Marc Faber he's
out there saying that well the markets
are going to fall like an avalanche so
we have David Stockman Mark barber
Charles men are we have cliff hi Harry
dent all pretty much saying the same
things that this economy is going to
come down it's going to come down hard
and remember how it was in 2008 where
you saw on the news people leaving their

their pensions they lost their wealth
they lost their homes well we're going
to see the same thing happen once again
but the central bank's the US government
they didn't make it better all they did

they pretended they create this illusion
that everything was fine and when
hits everything won't be fine why do you
think they came up with the baling
